questions.text: What is the first investigation you would advise to a patient with a large thyroid swelling?
questions.solution:
Assessing the biochemical function of the thyroid i.e. thyroid function test (TFT) is the first investigation done in any thyroid condition.

Assessment of TSH, T3, and T4 is done. However, TSH is most helpful in determining the management plan, especially in patients with thyroid nodules who clinically appear to be euthyroid.

Modalities for evaluation of thyroid swelling include:

  • Laboratory evaluation
    • TSH
    • T3
    • T4 
  • Thyroid imaging
    • Ultrasound
    • Radioisotope scanning
    • CT/MRI
  • Biopsy techniques
    • Fine needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB)
    • Tru-cut/core-needle biopsy

questions.text: A patient presents with a 2.5 cm neck swelling which is firm, non-tender, and moves on swallowing. TSH, T3, and T4 levels are normal. An ultrasound reports the swelling to be cystic and regular with low suspicion for malignancy. What is the next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Perform an fine needle aspiration biopsy
Reassure the patient and monitor periodically

questions.solution:
Fine needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy needs to be performed for further evaluation of the nodule.

In cases where the FNAC is inconclusive, tru-cut or open biopsy can be done. However, this is rarely required.

FNAC reporting systems are given as: 

Royal College of Pathologists, UK classification Bethesda Criteria    Description Usual Management

Thy 1

Thy 1c

 I Nondiagnostic or unsatisfactory Repeat FNA with image guidance
 Thy 2 II Benign Clinical follow-up
  Thy 3 III Atypia of undetermined significance/follicular lesion of undetermined significance Repeat FNA or lobectomy
IV Follicular neoplasm or suspicious for follicular neoplasm  Lobectomy
 Thy 4 V Suspicious for malignancy  Lobectomy or total thyroidectomy
 Thy 5 VI Malignant  Total thyroidectomy

questions.text: FNAC is useful in all types of thyroid cancers except _____
questions.solution:
FNAC is not useful in the diagnosis of follicular carcinoma of thyroid as it cannot differentiate between benign and malignant follicular lesion. Trucut biopsy is used to differentiate between them as follicular thyroid malignancy is defined by capsular and vascular invasion. 

Limitations of FNAC in thyroid disorders:

  • Cannot distinguish between follicular carcinoma and adenoma
  • Cannot distinguish between Hurthle cell carcinoma and adenoma
  • Not useful in Reidel’s thyroiditis

questions.text:
Which of the following carcinomas of the thyroid arise from the marked cells?
  1. Papillary
  2. Follicular
  3. Hurthle cell
  4. Anaplastic
  5. Medullary
questions.solution:
The cell marked in the image is a follicular cell of the thyroid gland. Papillary, follicular, and anaplastic thyroid carcinoma are all cancers of the follicular epithelium of the thyroid. Hurthle cell carcinoma is a variant of follicular thyroid carcinoma.

questions.text: What is the most common thyroid malignancy in iodine-deficient regions?
questions.solution:
Follicular thyroid carcinoma is the most common thyroid malignancy in iodine-deficient areas.

Papillary thyroid carcinoma is the most common thyroid malignancy in iodine-sufficient areas, children, and radiation-exposed areas.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a Thy3 lesion on FNAC was posted for hemithyroidectomy. Histopathology of the frozen section is given below. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
Capsular invasion as seen in the image confirms the presence of follicular carcinoma. Hence, total thyroidectomy is the recommended management.

As FNAC shows Thy3 lesion which is a follicular neoplasm, the frozen section of the excised specimen has to be evaluated. The presence of capsular or vascular invasion confirms the presence of follicular carcinoma.

Surgical management of differentiated thyroid cancers (DTCs) is as follows:

Extent of cancer Surgery done

Low-risk DTC
(Fulfilling all 5 of the following conditions)

  1. < 40 years (better prognosis)
  2. Unifocal lesion
  3. Size < 2 cm
  4. No lymphovascular invasion
  5. No capsular invasion
 Hemithyroidectomy

High-risk DTC without LN involvement
(not fulfilling any of the above 5 conditions)

 Total thyroidectomy

High-risk DTC + level VI LN involved

 Total thyroidectomy + Central neck dissection

High-risk DTC + other cervical LNs involved

 Total thyroidectomy + Modified radical neck dissection

Related Pearl: Follicular thyroid malignancy

It is more common in iodine-deficient areas. It is associated with p53, PTEN, PAX/PPAR-gamma, RAS, miRNA (miR-197 and miR-346).

It commonly presents as solitary thyroid nodules and the mean age of presentation is 50 years. It can also occur in long-standing cases of multinodular goitre.

FNAC is unable to distinguish between benign and malignant follicular lesions as malignancy is defined by capsular and vascular invasion. Hence, Trucut biopsy is required to confirm malignancy.

Histological findings:

  • Encapsulated
  • Uniform microfollicles or sheets of cells devoid of colloid
  • Capsular and vascular invasion indicates malignancy
  • Tumour thrombus within middle thyroid/ jugular veins may be seen at the time of surgery

Vascular (hematogenous) dissemination is common, with metastases to bone, lungs, liver, and elsewhere. The prognosis depends largely on the extent of invasion and stage at presentation.

Serum thyroglobulin levels are used for monitoring tumour recurrence, as they are undetectable after complete treatment.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about follicular thyroid carcinoma except:

choices.text: Thyroglobulin levels can be used to monitor patients for recurrence
Hematogenous spread is more common than lymphatic spread
Mortality rate is twice that of papillary thyroid carcinoma

questions.solution:
Osteolytic bone metastasis is seen in follicular thyroid carcinoma and not osteoblastic lesions.

Thyroglobulin trends may be used to monitor patients with differentiated thyroid cancer for a recurrence. Following total thyroidectomy, thyroglobulin levels must be undetectable.

All thyroid carcinoma, except medullary thyroid carcinoma, have osteolytic bony metastasis. Medullary thyroid cancer has osteoblastic bony metastasis.

Differentiated thyroid carcinomas (papillary & follicular):

Past history Radiation exposure Long-standing goitre
Risk factor Iodine-sufficient areas Iodine-deficient areas
Metastatic spread via Lymphatics > Hematogenous Hematogenous > Lymphatics
Diagnosis by FNAC Useful Not useful
Prognosis More favourable Less favourable

Related Pearl: Follicular thyroid malignancy

It is more common in iodine-deficient areas. It is associated with p53, PTEN, PAX/PPAR-gamma, RAS, miRNA (miR-197 and miR-346).

It commonly presents as solitary thyroid nodules and the mean age of presentation is 50 years. It can also occur in long-standing cases of multinodular goitre.

FNAC is unable to distinguish between benign and malignant follicular lesions as malignancy is defined by capsular and vascular invasion. Hence, Trucut biopsy is required to confirm malignancy.

  • Encapsulated
  • Uniform microfollicles or sheets of cells devoid of colloid

  • Tumour thrombus within middle thyroid/ jugular veins may be seen at the time of surgery

Predominantly osteoblastic:

  • Prostate cancer

  • Medullary carcinoma thyroid

Mixed osteoblastic and osteolytic:

  • Breast cancer(preponderance toward osteolytic)
  • Lymphoma

  • Multiple myeloma 
  • Thyroid carcinoma(except medullary carcinoma thyroid)
  • Gastrointestinal tract carcinoma

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 

The mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade and is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion.

It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan. Histological findings include:

  • Branching papillae 
  • Follicles with the fibrovascular stalk
  • Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes- 
    • Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei
    • Pseudo-inclusions
    • Nuclear grooves.

Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain.

It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

questions.text: A patient with a unilateral thyroid mass was diagnosed to have follicular thyroid carcinoma with involvement of level VI cervical lymph nodes. What is the appropriate management?

choices.text: Total thyroidectomy  with modified radical neck dissection
Total thyroidectomy with central neck dissection

questions.solution:
Patients with follicular thyroid carcinoma with level VI lymph node involvement are managed by total thyroidectomy with central neck dissection.

questions.text: A patient presented with a thyroid nodule. The USG showed an irregular hypoechoic mass with microcalcifications. Lymph nodes were not involved. FNAC showed a follicular neoplasm with predominantly Hurthle cells. Intra-op frozen section confirms capsular invasion. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Hurthle cell follicular carcinoma. The most appropriate management is total thyroidectomy with prophylactic central neck dissection. Hurthle cell carcinoma is a variant of follicular thyroid carcinoma.

As compared to follicular thyroid cancer, it has a poorer prognosis as it is more likely to metastasize. It is often bilateral and multifocal. The histological picture consists of predominantly oxyphil (Hurthle, Askanazy) cells containing abundant mitochondria. It cannot be diagnosed solely by FNAC as these cancers are characterized by vascular & capsular invasion.

Surgical management of Hurthle cell carcinoma:

Extent of cancer Surgery done
Unilateral Hurthle cell adenoma Hemithyroidectomy
Bilateral involvement without level VI LNs involvement Total thyroidectomy +  Central neck dissection (prophylactic)
Hurthle cell carcinoma with level VI LNs involved Total thyroidectomy +  Central neck dissection (therapeutic)
Hurthle cell carcinoma with other LNs involved Total thyroidectomy + Modified radical neck dissection

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman came to the surgeon with a thyroid swelling that had developed a year ago. On examination, the swelling was 3 cm in size, firm and immobile. Further, lymphadenopathy was present. A biopsy of the swelling is given below. Which of the following is incorrect regarding management and post-op care in this condition?

choices.text: Thyroxine is withheld after the surgery

questions.solution:
The given histological image depicts papillary formation with a fibrovascular stalk, characteristic orphan annie eye nuclei and psammoma bodies, diagnostic of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.
Total thyroidectomy with central neck dissection would be the appropriate management in this condition, because there is lymphadenopathy, although the tumour size is less than 4 cm.

Surgical management of differentiated thyroid cancers (DTCs) is as follows:

Extent of cancer Surgery done

Low-risk DTC
(Fulfilling all 5 of the following conditions)

  1. < 40 years (better prognosis)
  2. Unifocal lesion
  3. Size ~ 1-4 cm
  4. No lymphovascular invasion
  5. No capsular invasion

High-risk DTC without LN involvement / not fulfilling any of the above 5 conditions

questions.text: Which of the following describes lateral aberrant thyroid?

choices.text: Defective development of the fourth pharyngeal pouch
Metastatic thyroid cancer in lymph nodes
Cystic swelling of the thyroglossal duct

questions.solution:
Lateral aberrant thyroid almost always represents metastatic thyroid cancer in lymph nodes.

Thyroid tissue situated lateral to the carotid sheath and jugular vein found along the course of the thyroglossal duct was previously termed lateral aberrant thyroid. It is associated with papillary thyroid cancer in the ipsilateral thyroid lobe.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man came to the surgery OPD with a midline neck swelling. He does not have any other complaints. The patient had received chemoradiation for Hodgkin’s lymphoma nearly 20 years ago. On palpation, the mass is about 3 cm in size, non-tender, hard, fixed, and seems to arise from the right lobe of the thyroid. TSH levels were raised. A radioiodine uptake study showed cold nodule. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of radiation therapy to the head and neck for Hodkin's lymphoma and a cold nodule on radioiodine uptake scan are suggestive of papillary thyroid cancer.

Radiation exposure is an identifiable aetiological factor in the development of differentiated thyroid cancer (follicular and papillary thyroid cancer). The most important factor, however, is irradiation of the thyroid before 5 years of age.

Thyroid lymphomas are non-Hodgkin’s B-cell lymphomas. They present with B-symptoms like fever, night sweats, and weight loss in addition to neck swelling. Thus, thyroid lymphoma is an unlikely diagnosis. Thyroid lymphomas often develop in the setting of lymphocytic infiltration. 

In the town of Gomel, Ukraine, the incidence of childhood thyroid cancer rose from <1 per million to 96 per million following the Chernobyl nuclear disaster.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland. Laboratory studies reveal low T3, T4, high TSH and the presence of anti-TPO antibodies. FNAC from the gland shows enlarged cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm. Which of the following malignancies is commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical case scenario is suggestive of Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Thyroid lymphoma or malignant lymphoma is associated with long-standing Hashimoto’s thyroiditis.

Thyroid lymphomas are usually non-Hodgkin’s lymphomas, often associated with long-standing Hashimoto’s thyroiditis (autoimmune lymphocytic thyroiditis).

The clinical features include: B - symptoms i.e. fever, night sweats, and weight loss

As FNAC cannot characterize lymphoma, Tru-Cut biopsy is preferred. Chemotherapy and radiation therapy are often sufficient. Total thyroidectomy is indicated only in residual/recurrent disease.

A chemotherapy regimen (RCHOP) is the first line of management.
R - Rituximab
C - Cyclophosphamide
H - Hydroxydaunorubicin (Adriamycin)
O - Oncovin (Vincristine)
P - Prednisolone

The prevalence of thyroid lymphoma is 80 times higher in people with Hashimoto’s thyroiditis as compared to the normal population.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman has a history of papillary thyroid carcinoma left untreated for 2 years. She complains that the rapid enlargement in her neck swelling over the last month has made it difficult for her to swallow and talk. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Local invasion of the surrounding structures

questions.solution:
An elderly woman with rapidly enlarging neck mass and dysphagia in the setting of an untreated papillary carcinoma suggests a diagnosis of anaplastic thyroid cancer.

Anaplastic thyroid cancer, a poorly differentiated thyroid carcinoma, is the most aggressive cancer and has the worst prognosis of all thyroid malignancies. 

It usually occurs in elderly females. The typical manifestation is an with rapidly enlarging neck mass, dysphagia, and cervical tenderness. Patients usually have a history of untreated differentiated thyroid carcinoma (DTC). Local invasion to the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) causes hoarseness. It may also cause tracheal obstruction. Distant metastasis is more common in the lungs via the hematogenous route.

Diagnosis is made by FNAC. However, trucut/open biopsy is frequently used to confirm the diagnosis in cases of doubt.

Management:

  • If metastasis is absent: Total thyroidectomy + LN dissection
  • If metastasis is present: Palliative care with chemotherapy and radiotherapy
  • If tracheal obstruction: Isthmectomy to relieve obstruction

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman was brought in a dehydrated state and complains of loose stools. On examination, a tender neck swelling was found which was found to be present for 1 year. Histopathology of the swelling shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC). Histopathology shows the presence of amyloid deposits that are derived from the altered calcitonin molecules.

Medullary thyroid carcinoma is a tumor of parafollicular or C cells of the thyroid gland. They are derived from the neural crest cells of the ultimobranchial bodies. 

Most of the MTCs occur sporadically. However, around a quarter of the cancers are associated with familial MTC, MEN2A, and MEN2B.

Patients with sporadic MTC present at an older age, whereas patients with familial MTC usually present at a younger age. Features of MTC include:

  • Painful neck mass with cervical lymphadenopathy
  • Dysphagia, dysphonia or dyspnea if locally invaded
  • Diarrhoea due to increased intestinal motility by serotonin
  • Cushingoid habitus due to ectopic ACTH production
  • Metastasis is blood-borne
  • Microscopically, they consist of sheets of neoplastic cells separated by collagen and amyloid stroma

It is diagnosed by careful family history, physical examination, raised calcitonin, CEA levels, and fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the mass.

Total thyroidectomy with central neck node dissection is the treatment of choice in MTC patients. External beam radiotherapy can be used in patients with unresectable tumors. Targeted therapy can be considered using vandetanib, sorafenib, sunitinib, and cabozantinib.

Prophylactic total thyroidectomy should be considered within 5years of age in MEN2A mutation and within 1year of age in MEN2B mutation.

questions.text:
Choose the substances secreted by medullary thyroid carcinoma:
  1. Calcitonin
  2. Carcinoembryonic antigen
  3. Serotonin
  4. Thyroglobulin
  5. Histaminidase
questions.solution:
Medullary thyroid tumors secrete calcitonin, serotonin, histaminadases, and CEA (carcinoembryonic antigen).

Related Pearl: Secretion of medullary thyroid tumors

Medullary thyroid tumor secrete the following:

  • Calcitonin
  • Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)
  • Calcitonin gene–related peptide
  • Histaminadases
  • Prostaglandins E 2 and F 2 α
  • Serotonin

Calcitonin and serotonins are responsible for diarrhea in MTC.

questions.text: A patient with medullary thyroid carcinoma is posted for surgery. He is nearly 6.5 ft tall, with a slender build and elongated digits. What is the screening test that should be done pre-operatively?
questions.solution:
This patient with medullary thyroid carcinoma and features of marfanoid habitus (very tall patient with long, slender fingers and toes) is suggestive of MEN 2B syndrome. Such patients are to be screened for pheochromocytoma by measuring urinary catecholamines.

Pheochromocytoma, if present, should be treated first, and then MTC is to be treated next.

A thyroid swelling with elevated calcitonin indicates a medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC). MTC can either be sporadic (80%) or familial (RET gene mutation). In case of familial medullary thyroid carcinoma, stimulation with pentagastrin increases the release of calcitonin. This can be used for the screening of medullary thyroid carcinoma.

MTC can be inherited as a part of autosomal dominant (AD) syndromes such as:

  • Familial MTC
  • MEN 2A
  • MEN 2B

Prophylactic total thyroidectomy should be considered within 5years of age in MEN2A mutation and within 1year of age in MEN2B mutation.

Note: Serum calcium is measured to screen for parathyroid adenoma in MEN 2A.

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with medullary thyroid carcinoma. Which of the following could be used to screen the rest of her family?
questions.solution:
Screening of patients with familial MTC was historically done using pentagastrin stimulation test for calcitonin levels to make the diagnosis. 

Pentagastrin is a synthetic gastrin analogue. It acts on the CCK-B/gastrin receptor of the C cells and increases the basal rate of calcitonin secretion.

Basal calcitonin level = total C cell mass x rate of secretion.

Medullary thyroid tumors secrete calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), but also other peptides such as calcitonin gene-related peptide, histaminadases, prostaglandins E2 and F2α, and serotonin.

Another test that can be used for screening is calcium-stimulated calcitonin levels.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female was diagnosed with medullary thyroid carcinoma. On USG paratracheal lymph node involvement was found. What is the best method of management of this patient?

choices.text: Total thyroidectomy with central neck dissection
Total thyroidectomy with central neck dissection and RAI ablation
Total thyroidectomy with  modified radical and central neck dissection
Total thyroidectomy with lateral and central neck dissection

questions.solution:
Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) with Level VI or paratracheal lymph node involvement is managed with total thyroidectomy with central neck dissection and modified radical neck dissection.

Surgical management of MTC is as follows:

Extent of cancer Surgery done

MTC without LN involvement

 Total thyroidectomy + Central neck dissection (prophylactic)

MTC + level VI LN involved

 Total thyroidectomy + Central neck dissection (therapeutic) + Modified radical neck dissection (prophylactic)

MTC + other LNs involved

 Total thyroidectomy + Central neck dissection + Modified radical neck dissection (therapeutic)

Note: Prophylactic neck dissection is not routinely performed in papillary or follicular carcinoma.

questions.text: Prophylactic thyroidectomy is indicated in patients with which of the following features:

choices.text: Marfanoid habitus, multiple neuromas on the lip and familial pheochromocytoma,
Dense lymphatic infiltration of the thyroid detected on FNAC

questions.solution:
Prophylactic thyroidectomy is indicated in MEN 2B syndrome as they can develop medullary thyroid carcinoma. This syndrome manifests as:

  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Marfanoid habitus
  • Mucosal neuromas
  • Medullary thyroid cancer. 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) can be inherited as familial MTC, MEN 2A or MEN 2B syndromes. These conditions are autosomal dominant and occur due to RET proto-oncogene mutation. As almost all cases of MEN 2B develop medullary thyroid cancer, a prophylactic thyroidectomy may be performed even during infancy.

Option A: The most common malignancy in thyroglossal cysts is papillary thyroid carcinoma. In such a case, Sistrunk operation with total thyroidectomy is considered.

Option C: Hashimoto's thyroiditis shows dense lymphatic infiltration of the thyroid detected on FNAC which is treated with thyroxine. However, total thyroidectomy is performed in malignant transformation to thyroid lymphoma.

Option D: Upregulation of BRAF is associated with papillary thyroid carcinoma.

questions.solution:

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the 8th edition AJCC staging of thyroid neoplasms?

choices.text: In DTC, distant metastasis is IVB
In staging, age barrier is 55 years
N1a includes level VI and VII

questions.solution:
Minor extrathyroidal extension detected only on histological examination is removed from the definition of T3 disease and therefore has no impact on either T category or overall stage.

Differentiated Thyroid Cancer:

  • The age cutoff used for staging is increased from 45 to 55 years of age at diagnosis. 
  • N1 disease no longer upstages a patient to stage III. If < 55 years of age at diagnosis, N1 disease is stage I. If ≥ 55 years of age, N1 disease is stage II.
  • T3a is a new category for tumors > 4 cm confined to the thyroid gland
  • T3b is a new category for tumors of any size demonstrating gross extrathyroidal extension into strap muscles (sternohyoid, sternothyroid, thyrohyoid or omohyoid muscles)
  • Level VII lymph nodes, previously classified as lateral neck lymph nodes (N1b) is re-classified as central neck lymph nodes (N1a) to be more anatomically consistent and because level VII presented significant coding difficulties for tumor registrars, clinicians and researchers.
  • In differentiated thyroid cancer, the presence of distant metastases (M1) in older patients is classified as IVB disease rather than IVC disease. Distant metastasis in anaplastic thyroid cancer continues to be classified as IVC disease.

Minimal or occult/microcarcinoma are tumors 1 cm or less in size. They have no evidence of local invasiveness through the thyroid capsule or angioinvasion. Occult malignancies are usually not associated with lymph node metastases. However, about 25% of patients with these tumors have associated occult lymph node metastases. These are nonpalpable and are found incidentally at operative and histologic examinations or at autopsy.

questions.text: Which of the following will not be a treatment option for a pregnant patient with papillary thyroid carcinoma?

choices.text: Total Thyroidectomy plus Lymph node dissection

questions.solution:
Radioiodine ablation of thyroid is contraindicated in pregnant women due to risk of radiation exposure to the fetus. 

Therapeutic uses for radioactive iodine

  • In primary thyrotoxicosis after 45 years.
  • In autonomous toxic nodule after 45 years, it is useful as remaining gland still will function adequately after radiotherapy.
  • In follicular carcinoma of thyroid, after total thyroidectomy, if there are secondaries elsewhere in the body, as in bones or lungs, then I131 is given.

questions.text: A patient with papillary thyroid carcinoma underwent total thyroidectomy with central neck dissection, a month ago. At present, a whole-body iodine scan is positive. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Radio-iodine ablation is undertaken when a whole-body iodine scan is positive after a total thyroidectomy for any differentiated thyroid cancer (papillary or follicular carcinoma). 

The presence of any metastatic or residual thyroid tissue after total thyroidectomy can be detected by observing the uptake of radio-iodine in the entire body. To achieve effective uptake of radio-iodine, TSH levels need to be greatly increased, for example, by withdrawing thyroxine after the surgery for 4-6 weeks.

A positive whole-body iodine scan after total thyroidectomy indicates that there is either a metastatic or residual disease present. These patients are treated with I131 for radio-iodine ablation. 

A negative scan means there is no metastasis or residual thyroid tissue. They are followed up regularly with serum thyroglobulin, TSH and USG-neck.

If the tumour is resistant to radioiodine ablation, EBRT (external beam radiotherapy) is done.

Related Pearl: Radioiodine uptake of thyroid gland

Radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) scans are interpreted as follows:

  • High (or normal) radioiodine uptake indicates de-novo synthesis of the hormone. Therefore, there is increased hormone synthesis
  • Low (nearly absent) radioiodine uptake indicates:
    • Inflammation and destruction of thyroid tissue with release of the preformed hormone into the circulation
    • Extrathyroidal source of thyroid hormone

Conditions with high and low RAIU are given below:

High RAIU Low RAIU
  • Graves’ disease
  • Toxic multinodular goiter
  • Toxic adenoma
  • Thyroid cancer
  • Hydatidiform mole
  • TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma

 

 

 
  • Acute phase of Hashimoto’s thyroiditis
  • Drug-induced— iodine, amiodarone-induced thyroiditis
  • Subacute/ Dequervain thyroiditis
  • Radiation thyroiditis
  • Metastatic follicular thyroid carcinoma
  • Factitious (iatrogenic) thyrotoxicosis
  • Struma ovarii (extrathyroid source)
  • Hamburger thyrotoxicosis (exogenous source)

questions.text: A whole-body iodine scan is not useful in patients with which thyroid malignancy?
questions.solution:
After a total thyroidectomy, a whole-body iodine scan is not useful for detecting residual thyroid tissue or metastasis in medullary thyroid carcinoma.

Medullary thyroid carcinoma is a tumour of parafollicular or C cells. These cells which are derived from neural crest cells, do not take up iodine.  

A whole-body iodine scan is useful in thyroid tumours derived from follicular cells that take up iodine.

questions.text: Which of the following scales consider the completeness of surgical resection to determine the prognosis of a patient with thyroid cancer?
questions.solution:
MACIS scale includes completeness of the original surgical resection to determine the prognosis of the thyroid cancer.

Prognostic indicators of well differentiated thyroid cancers: 

  • AGES system - Age, histologic Grade, Extrathyroidal invasion, and metastases and tumor Size.
  • AMES system - Age (men <40 years old, women <50 years old), Metastases, Extrathyroidal spread, and Size of tumors (< or >5 cm).
    • DAMES - DNA aneuploidy + AMES
    • GAMES - Grade + AMES
  • TNM staging - Tumor, Nodal status, Metastases.
  • MACIS scale (postop modification) - distant Metastases, Age at presentation (<40 or >40 years old), Completeness of original surgical resection, extrathyroidal Invasion, and Size of original lesion (in centimeters).
